posts.author: 0rangeAGENT
posts.content:
I love to playing a character from level 1 all the way to 40.  Ideally, I would spend time at level 40 to get to enjoy all that power and the goodies earned.

This thread is for modules or sets of modules played back to back to take a new level 1 character to level 40, or close to it.

Please share your recommendations, and please include the starting level ranges and approximate ending levels for each module in the chain. Please don’t list PWs here, although offline versions are acceptable.

Here is a list of Module Chains:

Aielund (1 to 37-38)

Lord of Terror (1 to 28-30)
-> Sands of Fate (to 40)

Plague Campaign (OC) (1 to 18-20)
-> Aribeth’s Redemption (to 22-23?)
-> Mines of Twin Summit (to 40)

Shadows of Undrentide (1 to 12-15)
-> Nether Scrolls (to 15-17)
-> Hordes of the Underdark (to 26-27)
-> Sands of Fate (to 40)

Swordflight (1 to mid30s-40?)

World of Greyhawk - offline (1 to 40)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
And here's another possible chain for you. However, it does require you to be Good-aligned, and either human, elf, or half-elf. You go through the OC, then Aribeth's Redemption, then Sands of Fate. The trio of Redemption modules bring you back to Neverwinter immediately after Morag's defeat (not really a spoiler, I'm guessing) for Aribeth's trial and subsequent adventures.

Cheers

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Or there's the Lord of Terror, followed by Sands of Fate.

posts.author: 0rangeAGENT
posts.content: It sounds like you recommend Sands of Fate as the capper to a wide range of module types, Stag. I’m gonna have to prioritize playing SoF for sure!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Well, TBH, OrangeAGENT, Sands of Fate is one of the few level 40 modules that start with you at around level 27/8 (actually, it's the only one I can think of). Don't get me wrong, it's a perfectly fine and shiny thing, but for me, Aielund still rules (and you can certainly get to level 37 there: Mick's managed level 38 a time or two). Swordflight is tough, and I haven't engaged with it as fully as I'd like, but it's still a work in progress - currently at low-mid 30s, I believe - designed to end up at level 40 by its final installment. Mines of Twin Summit is a hack'n'slash blast, with very high magic. If you start that at around level 17 (pretty much when you finish the OC), you should manage level 40 not long after beginning its third part.

Cheers

posts.content: The excellent Adam Miler campaign, which is Shadowlord, Dream Catcher, and Demon, ends at about the same level as the OC, and so it could theoretically  be followed by MTS, but I haven't tried it.  SoU plus The Nether Scrolls might also work as "prequels" for MTS.
